headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; WEEK ENDED JAN. 12, 1935.

docs.snippet: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 13. -- Uruguay beat Peru, 1 to 0, today in the second match in the International Soccer Football Association's championship series. The game was witnessed by a crowd of 35,000, which filled the National Stadium.
docs.lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru, Jan. 13. -- Uruguay beat Peru, 1 to 0, today in the second match in the International Soccer Football Association's championship series. The game was witnessed by a crowd of 35,000, which filled the National Stadium.

headline.main: URUGUAY DOWNS PERU IN SOCCER MATCH, 1-0; Takes Second of International Title Series Before Crowd of 35,000 at Lima.

docs.snippet: GENEVA, Jan. 16. -- Creating a major precedent, the League of Nations Assembly's Chaco committee unanimously recommended tonight that all League members end their arms embargo in so far as it applies to Bolivia and strengthen it in so far as it...
docs.lead_paragraph: GENEVA, Jan. 16. -- Creating a major precedent, the League of Nations Assembly's Chaco committee unanimously recommended tonight that all League members end their arms embargo in so far as it applies to Bolivia and strengthen it in so far as it applies to Paraguay.
docs.abstract: League of Nations Chaco com votes unanimously to end arms embargo on Bolivia and to strengthen it against Paraguay; hints of stronger move

headline.main: LEAGUE SUPPORTS FIRST PUNITIVE ACT; CURB ON PARAGUAY; Assembly's Chaco Group Votes Unanimously for End of Arms Embargo on Bolivia.

docs.snippet: The progress made thus far in world economic recovery is now tending to "alleviate or remove" some of the conditions that caused defaults by foreign governments and their political subdivisions on dollar bonds outstanding in the United States,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The progress made thus far in world economic recovery is now tending to "alleviate or remove" some of the conditions that caused defaults by foreign governments and their political subdivisions on dollar bonds outstanding in the United States, according to a survey of foreign bond defaults completed yesterday by the Institute of International Finance, which is conducted by the Investment Bankers Association of America in cooperation with New York University.
docs.abstract: Inst of Internatl Finance repts on adjustment plans on dollar bond defaults

headline.main: WORLD CREDIT GAIN IS SEEN IN SURVEY; Finance Institute Says Many Foreign Governments Move to Settle External Debts.

docs.snippet: LONDON, Jan. 18. -- With thirteen days still to go before the lists are closed, the British Lawn Tennis Association, holder of the Davis Cup, today announced that fourteen nations had entered for the 1935 international tennis competititon, including...
docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, Jan. 18. -- With thirteen days still to go before the lists are closed, the British Lawn Tennis Association, holder of the Davis Cup, today announced that fourteen nations had entered for the 1935 international tennis competititon, including China, which has not played since 1928. The deadline is Jan. 31, with the draw scheduled for the next day.

headline.main: DAVIS CUP ENTRIES FILED BY 14 NATIONS; China Sends 1935 Challenge but Canada Definitely Will Be Out of Tourney.

docs.snippet: THE new year finds South America emerging from the trough of the depression. The continent is rebuilding after a hurricane that ripped along its length, destroying foreign trade, scattering gold reserves, upsetting monetary systems, wrecking...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE new year finds South America emerging from the trough of the depression. The continent is rebuilding after a hurricane that ripped along its length, destroying foreign trade, scattering gold reserves, upsetting monetary systems, wrecking industrial enterprises and the political structures on which these were based.

headline.main: SOUTH AMERICA ADVANCES; Her Recovery Efforts Have Been Attended by the Rise of Economic Nationalism, While Politically She Has Entered a Transition

docs.snippet: Credit conditions in the twenty-one Latin-American countries covered by the latest survey conducted by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men showed a sharp improvement for the last three months of 1934, William S. Swingle,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Credit conditions in the twenty-one Latin-American countries covered by the latest survey conducted by the foreign department of the National Association of Credit Men showed a sharp improvement for the last three months of 1934, William S. Swingle, head of the department, said yesterday.
docs.abstract: Survey of credit conditions in Latin-Amer

headline.main: CREDITS IMPROVE IN LATIN AMERICA; Collections Also Show Increase in Three Months' Survey of National Group.
